comment: Overall sorta a boring class, but the class is easy. 2-3 Quizzes a week and an 5 exams total with one dropped. You have to go to concerts outside of the classroom including 2 KSU ones and a professional one as well, which is definitely more work.

Sometimes lectures could feel boring, but Professor Thrower did his best to keep the class engaged even when it was near impossible to. He plays guitar and is knowledgeable about the structures and history of music, so I'd recommend taking him.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: Lecture can get pretty boring at times, but the professor is amazing and tries to make them entertaining Quizzes were multiple attempts so you could retake them to get a 100. Tests were all open note and he dropped the lowest. You will have to attend 3 concerts(1 professional and 2 on campus), which is more tedious than hard. Would take again.

Lecture heavy but he is very knowledgeable about what he's talking about. 2-3 weekly quizzes with multiple attempts available if you want to improve your grade. Class was subjectively boring but as long as you take the notes this is an easy A. Open note and open book for all tests and quizzes
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy

comment: He was a pretty good professor and the class was pretty easy! His tests are lockdown (not the camera ones) and are based off the PowerPoints. For quizzes he gives you 3 attempts. The lowest test grade is dropped. You have to attend 3 concerts (professional ones not like ur favorite artist) but over all pretty easy and a good class!

He's a great teacher overall. He is also pretty funny in a subtle way that makes lectures lighthearted. He likes interacting with the class to keep the energy up. You do have to memorize and be able to recognize different music styles for the tests.

Professor Thrower is a great teacher but he is very lecture heavy. Attendance is a MUST, he passes an attendance sheet around. Everything that is in the powerpoints are on the quizzes and tests. He does require the lockdown browser for tests but does not require the webcam. He sometimes gives free points on tests or makes the answer very obvious.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: There's multiple quizzes due each week, but you get three attempts and correct and wrong answers are given, so its not hard to get an 100. Lectures are mostly him talking and showing a few audio clips, but it's not too boring. Pretty easy class with a few tests and concert assignments that make up most of the grade.

This professor is fantastic. Easy class to pass, with the only downside being he requires attendance for a class that shouldn't require it. Super cool guy and funny. He cares about his students' success as well. Take him for an easy A!

Professor Thrower is a fine teacher, but he sticks far too much to what he is supposed to teach, and offers little of his own personal insight in music, which I KNOW he has. He runs his own blog focused on guitar performance, and he seems like a very smart guy. But in the classroom, he is a bit dull and awkward. However, you WILL pass the class.
Awesome professor, very understanding and willing to work with you.

Dr. Thrower is a good professor but the class itself isn't that interesting unless you genuinely are looking at music for a career. It is very easy and the only reason I got a B was because I lost focus at the end of the semester.
Took his class online this 2020 fall semester. Very clear in his teaching and what is expected of you. You don't have to do all the reading, but the lectures are 100% required to pass.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Hilarious

comment: Really nice guy. If you have a change to see him play in a guitar concert, please go: you won't be disappointed. Lectures are sometimes a bit boring but he makes it as interesting as possible with music history.

It's just quizzes and tests and going to concerts. If you forget to do a quiz that's your loss since he won't open it back up for you to take. The concerts are a hassle so do it ASAP and his tests are difficult but the study guides are a good help if you do them.

I took this class as an elective and I had to work harder for this class than my core classes. The tests are extremely difficult and webcam/lockdown browser. If you are taking this class as an elective I highly do not recommend it.

This class was boring if you're not into music and the material can be a bit tedious, but he dropped one out of the 5 tests we took, so that was cool. Sean takes attendance randomly. The tests are detail-oriented, but the study guides he puts out well prepare you for it. You are required to go to 3 concerts in total. Overall, not a bad choice.

This class is not an easy A. I struggled with the class more than my upper division courses. I took this class as an elective and I am very upset about it because I think I'll be getting a C. The tests are lockdownbrowser + Webcam and are extremely hard. Studying will not help with the tests because every question is extremely in depth.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Save yourself some time and only take this class if you're legitimately interested in learning about music. If you're looking for an easy A this is just not the way to go. TAKE IT ONLINE. He drops your lowest test, has no extra credit, has quizzes every Friday which are all on quizlets but tests are extremely difficult. Just take it online.

Sean is very, VERY interested in music. DO NOT take this class hoping to get an easy A. You'd need a BA in music to understand him, and his tests. This is NOT a "read the text and pass the test" class, you're graded on musical pieces by your ability pick them out by hearing them. Lockdown browser is also used, so good luck cheating. DO NOT TAKE HIM
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Professor Thrower is a Marvelous teacher. His presentation skills are great and he seems very comfortable infront of a crowd. He engages us with his impressive guitar skills. He genuinley cares about his student's questions and is very easy to talk to. However, the tests are VERY DIFFICULT! Study hard for his tests and go to a couple KSU concerts.

I had Professor Thrower last spring and while he is pretty new to teaching, he really made class enjoyable for his students! The lectures can be dry at times but he spices them up by playing guitar and singing. The tests are given online and can be difficult, but as long as you attend class they are manageable. Great teacher!
Straight forward professor. Gives study guides. Will be fine if you look over the powerpoints and study guides.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Amazing lectures

comment: Took him for my 8 am, made a Monday morning as energetic as possible. Always in a positive mood and was willing to work with his students. Have to attend 2 Ksu concerts and 1 aso but no papers for these events. Drops lowest test. Tests are hard and little details are focused on
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY

comment: Professor thrower was a great guy and funny. Class itself is boring but at least he was a nice and funny dude. Class itself is also easy and he gives study guides for the test.

Mr. Thrower overall is a pretty good professor. However, I had his class in the morning which was my fault. Tends to be boring listening to Beethoven and not paying attention. Besides that his class is lecture-based take good notes should pass. There is event attendance that counts towards your grade.

Attendance is mandatory, but he checks it randomly. He teaches right off of the slides and is pretty laidback. His tests include bonus questions and "gimme" questions strewn about. The online textbook is really helpful. Take the quizzes for each chapter before the tests and you should perform well. There was less than a minimal amount of homework.

easy if you have taken chorus, orchestra, music appreciation, or music theory. There are about 4 total tests and most of them are online through D2L and can be done from home. Class is heavy in music history such as Baroque, Classical, Middle Ages. Notes can be heavy, but class ends early lots of times. Need online code for textbook for studying.
